         <style type="text/css">
          #stickybanner,
#stickybanner #stickyheader {z-index:99998;}

          </script>

           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/extremesection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D204694%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article_sticky&amp;c=2153602&amp;tile=1">

     <div id="main">
      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/extreme" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Extreme category archives.">

        <li class="current_item">
         Star light, star bright: The first galaxies were filled with super-bright star clusters
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Star light, star bright: The first galaxies were filled with super-bright star clusters
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/jhruska" rel="author" title="Posts by Joel Hruska">
              Joel Hruska
             </a>
             on May 1, 2015 at 7:30 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="204694 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=204694" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/204694-star-light-star-bright-the-first-galaxies-were-filled-with-super-bright-star-clusters#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <div class="photo">
            <img alt="FirstStars" class="attachment-single wp-post-image" height="196" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/FirstStars-348x196.jpg" width="348"/>
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            As stars go, ours is a bit of a pipsqueak. As vital as Sol is to the continued existence of life on Earth, the advent of telescopy and the work of pioneering astronomers in the 19th and early 20th centuries quickly proved that the Sun wasnt just
            <em>
             a
            </em>
            star  compared with many of the true giants of the Milky Way, it was a bit underpowered. Now, research into the conditions at the beginning of the universe have predicted stellar clusters that would make R136a1  currently the brightest known star, at 7.4 million times the luminosity of our sun  look like it needed to hit the gym.
           </p>
           <p>
            Predicting the conditions following the Big Bang is obviously difficult, since we can only peer so far back in time. As the early clouds of helium and hydrogen condensed into increasingly dense clouds of gas, they wouldve given off bursts of luminescence. Once these gas clouds are dense enough that their own pressure cannot sustain them, they collapse. Today, its thought that supernova are a major source of this collapse  as a star explodes, the force of the explosion slams into pre-existing gas clouds nearby, compressing them, and possibly kickstarting the birth of a new generation of stars. In the time immediately after the Big Bang, this wouldnt have been possible.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_204696" style="width: 543px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/NASA-WMAP-first-stars.jpg">
             <img alt="Artists conception of the first stars. Image Credit: Wikipedia" class="size-full wp-image-204696" height="300" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/NASA-WMAP-first-stars.jpg" width="533"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Artists conception of the first stars. Image Credit: Wikipedia
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            <a href="https://www.ras.org.uk/news-and-press/2617-as-bright-as-a-hundred-million-suns-the-clusters-of-monster-stars-that-lit-up-the-early-universe">
             The current theory
            </a>
            is that after the Big Bang, there were still small local areas where material was gathered to a greater or lesser extent. Over time, these tiny fluctuations became the first stars  small, local fluctuations would fuse together first, then attract larger clumps of matter. The process wasnt particularly fast compared to the violence of a supernova, but over time, the building blocks of the first protostars would essentially self-assemble.
           </p>
           <p>
            Once the protostars began to interact with each other, they would periodically steal material from one another (if not combine completely). This would create intense surges of energy, with peak luminescence estimated at up to 16 million times the brightness of the sun.
           </p>
           <p>
            These first stars were extremely unstable. The high concentration of matter relative to the size of the universe meant that early stars grew to huge sizes. Modern hypergiant stars are known to periodically expel huge quantities of material. Still, these first stars may have been quite different than the stars we see today. One line of research suggests that they wouldve contained virtually no heavy metals since those materials are thought to have been created
            <em>
             inside
            </em>
            stars in the first place. Early stars may have been both massive and extremely luminous, but not necessarily all that dense.
           </p>
           <p>
            Either way, in the long run, these first stars went supernova or even hypernova. In doing so, they began seeding the interstellar void with the heavier elements and materials necessary for complex elements, rocky planets, and eventually, life. The James Webb telescope, with its superior infrared scanning capability, should allow us to peer farther back in time than we ever have before  possibly catching a glimpse of the universe less than a billion years after it came into existence.
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',

        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>

            </div>

             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',

        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">

          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">

            </h3>
           </div>

           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');

            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=204694';

            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">

           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Extreme'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Joel Hruska';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});

  <!-- This website is patched against a big problem not solved from WordPress 2.5+ to date -->
  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
